sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is an application made for burning CD-R/Ws and DVD-R/Ws. It is designed to be easy to use, while providing all the tools necessary for burning.
The following are the main features of Brasero:

listitem.para: Burns data to CD-R/Ws and DVD-R/Ws
Burns audio CDs from digital audio files (such as ogg, flac and mp3)
Copies CDs and DVDs
Creates image files and burns from existing image files
Erases CD-R/Ws and DVD-R/Ws
Checks the integrity of disks and disk images

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: You can start &app; in the following ways:

listitem.para: Choose Sound & Video Brasero Disc Burning.
Type brasero and then press Return.

note.para: If &app; is set as your default disc burning application, it will automatically start when you insert a blank CD-R/W or DVD-R/W in your drive.

sect1.para: When &app; is started you will see the following window:

textobject.phrase: The Brasero main window. Shows the menu bar and the four types of project to choose from.

sect1.para: This window is the starting point for all of your projects. You can click on the project type you wish to start from here. If you have created other projects with &app;, you will be able to select them from the section titled Choose a recently opened project (see for more information).

sect1.title: Creating a New Project
sect1.para: The following section explains the four types of project that you can create with &app;.

sect2.title: Audio Project
sect2.para: This section explains how to create an audio CD. This project takes selected audio files, converts them to a raw audio format and burns them to a CD which standard CD players can play.

To burn an audio CD:
Insert a blank CD-R into your drive.
Click Audio project in the main window or click
Project New Project New Audio Project .
In the pane to the left of the window, select Browse the file system from the drop-down list at the top and browse to the music files you want to add to you project.
You can also select the Search files using keywords option to search for music files, or the Display playlists and their contents option to select music from playlists on your computer.
Select the files you want by double-clicking on them, or by selecting them and clicking the Add button at the top left of the toolbar.
When all of the files have been added, click on Burn.
The Disc burning setup dialog will be shown; make any desired modifications (see ).
Click Burn to start the burning process.

note.para: When adding files, refer to the status bar at the bottom of the window to see how much space you are using on your CD. You may have to adjust the size of your CD to let &app; know what its actual capacity is. To do this, click on the button next to the status bar and select the size of your CD as quoted on the disc or its packaging.

tip.para: To save the project for later use, click on Project Save

sect3.title: Audio Project Options
sect3.para: Before starting the burning process, it is possible to modify some of the burning options.

varlistentry.term: Section Select a drive to write to:

listitem.para: Click Properties to open the properties dialog for the burning device. See for more information.
From the Number of copies spin box, select the number of copies of the disc you want to burn.
In the text box, enter the title you want to give to the disc. This title will be shown as the name of the disc.

term.guilabel: Leave the disc open to add a data session later

listitem.para: Select this option to create a multisession disc, so that it will be possible to add files to the disc at a later date (without erasing it, if it is rewritable).
Pause: After you have inserted your audio tracks. Highlight a track and click on the Pause button. This will add a 2 second pause after that track.
Split: Select a track and click on the Split button. A window will pop up to let you choose where you want to split the track. In the Method drop down list are 4 options:

Split track manually: This allows you to select the time on the track where you wish to split it. A sliding bar is provided along with an audio preview, so you can pinpoint where you would like to split the track.
Split track in parts with a fixed length: This allows you to split the track into fixed-length parts which have a duration that you specify.
Split track in fixed number of parts: This allows you to select the number of parts that you want your track to be broken up into.
Split track for each silence: This will search the track for silences and split the track where it finds them.
Once you have split the tracks you can remove or merge the splits using the buttons on the right. Click OK when finished.

sect2.title: Data Project
sect2.para:
To burn a data CD:
Insert a blank CD-R/W or DVD-R/W into your drive.
Click Data project in the main window or click
Project New Project New Data Project .
Use the pane to the left of the window to find the files you want to add to the project. Select Browse the file system from the drop-down list at the top to browse for files, or select Search files using keywords to search for them.
Select the files you want by double-clicking on them, or highlighting them and clicking the Add button at the top left of the toolbar.
When all the files have been added, click Burn.
The Disc burning setup dialog will be shown; make any desired modifications (see ).
Click Burn to start the burning process.

sect3.title: Data Project Options
sect3.para: Before starting the burning process, it is possible to modify some of the burning options.

varlistentry.term: Section Select a drive to write to:

listitem.para: Click Properties to open the properties dialog for the burning device. See for more information.
From the Number of copies spin box select the number of copies of the disc you want to burn.
In the text box, enter a label to identify the disc. This label will be shown as the name of the disc.

Select this option if you intend the disc to be used on computers running Windows. Files on the disc will be checked to ensure that their filenames do not contain characters which are invalid on Windows.

term.guilabel: Leave the disc open to add other files later

listitem.para: Select this option to create a multisession disc, so that it will be possible to add files to the disc at a later date (without erasing it, if it is rewritable).

sect2.title: Disc Copy
sect2.para:
This project lets you take an existing disc and copy it to a blank disc or image file. To copy a disc:
Insert the CD or DVD you wish to copy into your drive.
Click Disc copy in the main window or click
Project New Project Copy Disc .
The CD/DVD copy options dialog will be shown; make the desired modifications (see for more information).
Click Copy to start the copying process.

sect3.title: Disc Copy Options
sect3.para: Before starting the copying process, it is possible to modify some of the copying and burning options.

varlistentry.term: Section Select source drive to copy:

listitem.para: From the drop-down list, select the drive that holds the disc you want to copy. Information about the disc in that drive will be shown below.

varlistentry.term: Section Select a drive to write to:

listitem.para: From the drop-down menu, select the drive to write the disc copy to.
From this drop-down menu, select File image to create a disc image, such as an ISO image.
Click Properties to open the properties dialog for the burning device. See for more information.
From the Number of copies spin box, select the number of copies of the disc you want to burn.

note.para: If you have more that one drive on you system, you can use one drive as the source drive and the other as the destination drive. If you do not, you will be prompted to remove the CD or DVD you are copying and insert your blank media.

sect2.title: Burn Image
sect2.para:
This project takes an existing file image and burns it to a CD-R/W or DVD-R/W. &app; supports the following types of image file:
.iso
.raw
.cue
.toc

To start this project:
Insert a blank CD-R/W or DVD-R/W into your drive.
Click Burn image in the main window or click
Project New Project Burn Image .
The Image burning setup dialog will be shown; make the desired modifications (see ).
Click Burn to start the burning process.

sect3.title: Burn Image Options
sect3.para: Before starting the image burning process, it is possible to modify some of the burning options.

varlistentry.term: Section Select a drive to write to:

listitem.para: Click Properties to open the properties dialog for the burning device. See for more information.
From the Number of copies spin box select the number of copies of the disc you want to burn.
Click on the button next to Path to open the Open an image dialog and select the image file to burn.
From the drop-down menu, select the type of image to burn. If unsure, select Let brasero choose (safest).

sect2.title: Burning Device Properties
sect2.para: Before starting the burning process, it is possible to change some of the properties for the burning device that will be used.

listitem.para: From the drop-down menu, select the burning speed. For the best value, check the CD/DVD case.

warning.para: Burning a disc with a higher speed than supported could create an unreadable disc. Use lower burning speeds to reduce the chance of this happening.

term.guilabel: Burn the image directly without saving it to disc

listitem.para: Select this option if you want to burn the image directly onto the media, without saving it to the hard disk and without creating an image file.

term.guilabel: Use burnproof (decrease the risk of failure)

listitem.para: Select this option to prevent the buffer underrun effect (or buffer underflow). This is when the computer is not fast enough to deliver data to the burning device at the selected burning speed.

warning.para: If a buffer underrun takes place, the burned disc could be unreadable.

listitem.para: Select this option the simulate the burning process; no real burn is performed. This is useful for testing, if you are having problems burning discs.
Select this option to eject the media in the burning device once the burning process has completed.
From the drop-down menu, select the directory to use for storing the temporary files created for the burning process.
The default directory is /tmp.

sect1.title: Opening a Saved Project
sect1.para:
If you have recently saved a project, you can open it again in one of the following ways:
Choose Project Recent Projects and select the project you want to open.
From the main window, click on the project you want to open under Choose a recently opened project.

To open a project which does not appear in Recent Projects, click
Project Open and select the project file.
Once opened, you can add or remove files from the project, burn it to disc, and then save it again for later use.

sect1.title: Erasing a CD or DVD
sect1.para:
Erasing or blanking a CD or DVD means to delete all the data that the CD or the DVD contains. &app; is able to erase the following CD and DVD formats:
CD-RW
DVD-RW (single or dual layer)
DVD+RW (single or dual layer)
In general, &app; can support all of the media formats supported by your own CD/DVD recorder.

warning.para: Make sure that the media you want to erase is erasable. Check the media case for more information.

sect1.para:
To erase a CD-RW or a DVD-RW:
Insert the erasable CD or DVD in your drive.
From the menu bar, choose Tools Erase... . The Disc blanking dialog will be shown.
From the drop-down list named Select a recorder, select the drive that holds the disc you want to erase.
If you want to quickly erase the disc, select the fast blanking option (for more information, see ).
Press the Blank button to start erasing the CD or DVD.

warning.para: The blanking process will permanently destroy all of the data on the disc.

sect2.title: What is fast blanking?
sect2.para: Fast blanking is a way of quickly erasing a disc. This method is much faster than fully erasing the disc, and is sufficient to allow the disc to be written to again.
The full erasing procedure is slower but is more secure, as it removes all traces of previous data. Data removed from fast blanked media can still be recovered with special tools.

sect1.title: Checking the Integrity of a CD or DVD
sect1.para: Checking the integrity of a CD or DVD makes sure that the files written to the disc are intact and have not been corrupted during the burning process.

The integrity check is done using the MD5 digest algorithm, which creates a fingerprint of the data on the media. Each time you burn a CD or DVD, and the md5sum plugin is enabled (see for more information), &app; adds a MD5 file to the disc in order to perform integrity checks at a later date.
&app; performs an integrity check after each burning session, checking the automatically generated file. Usually this process is longer than using an external MD5 file.

To check the integrity of a disc:
Insert the CD or DVD to be checked into the drive.
From the menu bar, choose Tools Check integrity , or press Ctrl F .
You can check the integrity by using a MD5 file or by letting &app; automatically perform a check on the media.
Select the Use a md5 file to check the disc option to use an MD5 file.
Click on the None button under the previously mentioned option and select an MD5 file, usually ending with the .md5 extension.
Click on the Check button to start the integrity check.
If the integrity check is successful, &app; will notify you with a File integrity check success dialog; otherwise, the File integrity check error dialog will be displayed.

sect1.title: Plugins
sect1.para: &app; can use different plugins to perform different tasks. There are several plugins you can choose from.

To view available plugins, press
Edit Plugins . The plugins that you can use are:

row.entry: Enables &app; to burn files which are not stored locally.
Enables &app; to perform integrity checks on discs after they have been burnt. Also enables the writing of a small file which holds the MD5 sum of all the files on the disc.
Enables &app; to perform integrity checks on discs by using a file containing the MD5 sum.

sect1.para: To enable or disable a plugin, click on the check box next to it.

note.para: In order to use some of the plugins listed here, it may be necessary to install further applications on your system. See your operating system documentation for more information.
